segments.text: ओम अज्ञानति मिरान्दस्या ज्ञानान्जुनिषलाकया चक्षिरुन्मीलितं येनातस्मै श्रीगुरवे नमः
नमा ओम विष्णु पादाया कृष्ण प्रेष्ठाय भूतले श्रीमते भक्ति वेदान्त स्वामिन्निति नामिने
नमस्ते सारस्वते देवे गव्रभाणी प्रचारिने निर्विशेश शुन्यवादी पाश्चात्य देशतारिने
जय श्री कृष्ण चैतन्या प्रभूनित्यानन्दा श्री अद्वैत गदाधर श्रीवासादी गव्रभक्त वृन्दा
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Jai Vanarottamam
Devim Sarasvatim Vyasam Tato Jaya Mudhirayet
In this session we will be discussing from the 40th verse of the 9th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
Lalitha Gati Vilasa Valguhasa Pranaya Niriksana Kalpitoru Manaha
Krita Manu Krita Vatya Unma Dandhaha Prakritim Agan Kilayasya Gopa Vadhvaha
The meaning of this verse is, let my mind be fixed upon Lord Sri Krishna,
whose motions and smiles of love attracted the damsels of Raja Dharma, the Gopis.
The damsels imitated the characteristic movements of the Lord after his disappearance from the Rasa dance.
This is yet another precept.
This is the same prayer offered by Bhishma Deva to Lord Krishna.
Bhishma is fixing his mind upon Lord Sri Krishna and remembering the different pastimes of Krishna.
Smaranam, remembering the pastimes of Krishna, remembering the form of Krishna, remembering the name of Krishna, remembering the qualities of Krishna.
This is bhakti. This is the practice of bhakti.
Here, specifically, Bhishma Deva is remembering Krishna's pastimes with his topmost devotees, the Gopis of Vrindavan.
So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains what is the characteristic of,
the Gopis' devotion to Krishna.
It is explained by Srila Prabhupada in the purport,
By intense ecstasy in loving service, the damsels of Vraja Bhumi, that is the Gopis,
attained qualitative oneness with the Lord by dancing with him on an equal level,
by embracing him in nuptial love,
by smiling at him,
by looking at him in joke,
and by looking at him with a loving attitude.
The Gopis are in a relationship with Krishna in conjugal love.
Conjugal love means love between opposite genders.
Actually, Krishna is the only male,
and everyone else is female.
Krishna is the only Purusha, everyone else is Prakriti.
So, this love between Krishna and the devotees is natural,
is our constitutional position.
So, among the devotees of Krishna,
the topmost devotees are the Gopis.
Now, Srila Prabhupada says,
the relation of the Lord with Arjuna is undoubtedly praiseworthy
for devotees like Bhishma Deva,
because Arjuna's friendship with the Lord was very, very intimate friendship.
It was transcendental relationship,
not material friendship.
But, the relation of the Gopis with the Lord is still more praiseworthy
because of their still more purified loving service.
Now, how is Gopis' devotional service more purified?
To understand that, Srila Prabhupada explains,
that according to Lord Chaitanya Mahaprabhu,
ramyakachit upasana vrajavadhu vargena yakalpita
The meaning of this is,
this is what Chaitanya Mahaprabhu says about
the Gopis' devotional service rendered to Lord Krishna.
There is no better method of worship
than the system invented by the Gopis.
Worship of Krishna.
The best method of worship is that which was performed by the Gopis of Vrindavan.
So, the Gopis' invention of worshipping Krishna
was to remain always
Krishna conscious
without any material profit.
That is the super excellence of the Gopis.
Super excellent devotional service.
They never expected any return from Krishna.
That was not their business.
Their attitude was not like,
Krishna, we have done so much for you.
Can you give us some benediction, Krishna?
No.
They never expected any benediction from Krishna.
Though Krishna is the Supreme Lord,
who is the only giver of all kinds of benedictions,
but the Gopis,
they never expected any benediction from Krishna.
Gopis' attitude was
that you take whatever you like from us,
but we do not ask anything in exchange, in return.
Nothing. We want nothing.
They simply want to please Krishna.
That's all.
They only want to see Krishna happy.
That's all.
We have got everything to give you,
and we have no need to ask you anything at all.
This is the Gopis' worship.
Generally, people worship the Supreme Lord
either because they are Artha,
Artha means they are in distress,
or they are in need,
or they are Artharthi,
or they are in desiring some wealth, some money.
So, they want some relief from some suffering,
or they want some money.
Two classes of people, Artha and Artharthi.
And another two classes of people who also worship God,
Jignasu and Jnani.
Jignasu means they are inquisitive to know
who is this God, or who is God.
Curiosity.
And Jnani are the ones who are after
pure knowledge of God.
In any case, all these four categories
of persons who approach Krishna,
they are classified as devotees,
but they want something in exchange
for their worship,
for their devotion.
They want something.
Whereas, the pure devotees
do not want anything in return for their worship
or in return for their service to Krishna.
Because they are approaching Krishna,
even such devotees who want something in exchange
are classified as devotees.
And they do get some spiritual benefit
because of approaching Krishna.
But they are not pure devotees.
Whenever the service is rendered,
devotional service is rendered with some motive,
expectation of something in return,
then the service is not considered
pure devotional service.
It is mixed devotional service.
So, the gopis' activities
in devotional service
are on the supreme platform of pure devotion.
This is the position of gopis.
This is the position of the gopis.
Therefore, Prabhupāda says,
the loving service of the gopis
is the topmost,
is most praiseworthy.
And,
the gopis, by their service,
they practically became one with the Lord
of attaining equal footing
with the Lord.
Now, Bhīṣma's aspiration
to remember the gopis
at the last stage of his life
is to have their mercy also.
Devotees generally want
mercy of Krishna
and his pure devotees.
Bhīṣma is teaching us.
The Lord, Supreme Lord Krishna,
is always more satisfied
when his pure devotees are glorified.
And, therefore, Bhīṣma Deva
not only glorified
the activities of Arjuna,
but he also glorified
the activities of the gopis,
the topmost devotees of Krishna.
Now, the gopis,
their equality,
which is being described here,
is one of perfect ecstasy,
in which
the differential conception
is completely eradicated.
Why?
Because,
in the gopis'
service to Kṛṣṇa,
